Dimethyl ether from methanol on mesoporous γ-alumina catalyst prepared from surfactant free highly porous pseudo-boehmite Seyedeh Afagh Hashemi Dehkordi a Mojtaba Golbodaqi a Anahita Mortazavi-Manesh a Nasser Safari a ⁎ Farzad Bahadoran b Mohammad Fatehi Haghighat a a Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry and Petroleum Science, Shahid Beheshti University, GC, 1983969411 Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry Faculty of Chemistry and Petroleum Science Shahid Beheshti University Tehran GC 1983969411 Iran aDepartment of Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry and Petroleum Science, Shahid Beheshti University, GC, 1983969411 Tehran, Iran b Gas Research Division, Research Institute of Petroleum Industry (RIPI), 1485733111 Tehran, Iran Gas Research Division Research Institute of Petroleum Industry (RIPI) Tehran 1485733111 Iran bGas Research Division, Research Institute of Petroleum Industry (RIPI), 1485733111 Tehran, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Different samples of mesoporous nano-sized γ-alumina were prepared through surfactant-free sol-gel process, using aluminum nitrate as precursor. The influence of variables such as addition of alcohol, metal salts and also effect of changing the aluminum source were investigated on the synthesis method. The products, which were obtained on different conditions, were then characterized by XRD, FT-IR, SEM, TEM. Moreover, textural properties were also measured by BET. To study thermal stability of prepared alumina; Cerium nitrate, magnesium nitrate, lanthanum nitrate and gadolinium nitrate were added as dopants. The catalytic performance of the synthesized mesoporous alumina (with a surface area of ​​272 m2/g, pore volume of 0.94 cm3/g and pore size of 13.8 nm) was studied for the methanol conversion to dimethyl ether, and the result was compared by commercial γ-alumina. Synthesized mesostructured catalyst has comparable activity and DME selectivity at 300°C to that of commercial alumina at 400 °C. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Mesoporous nano-sized alumina Pseudo-boehmite Surfactant-free Catalytic activity Methanol conversion Dimethyl ether (DME) Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Mesoporous aluminas have been widely employed as high performance materials in catalyst supports, ceramics, heat insulating substances, ion exchangers and reinforcements owing to their attractive properties such as high thermal stability, high surface area, large pore volume, narrow pore size distribution and specific morphologies [1–5]. The synthesis of crystalline Al2O3 nanoparticles has been reported by several techniques including sol-gel, hydrothermal, spray pyrolysis, laser ablation, microwave-assisted solvothermal and precipitation method [6–8]. The alumina exists in different crystal structures such as δ, η, γ, θ and α phase, etc. [9–14]. Among these phases, γ-Al2O3 possesses high specific surface area, which leads to high activity for a catalytic support and adsorption [15–18]. Gamma-alumina is accepted to have spinel structure of AB2O4 with FCC-packed oxygen sublattice in which divalent cations occupying tetrahedral and the trivalent cations occupying octahedral sites. Therefore, addition of rare earth metals as dopants could prevent γ to α phase transformation. Dopant ions occupy the available vacancies in the spinel structure of Al2O3 and reduce the velocity of this phase transformation by affecting cations arrangement [19,20]. In addition, mesoporous γ-alumina with high surface area, large pore volume and pore size is prepared by organic template or surfactant which are environmentally and economically undesired [21]. It is important to apply proper methods with use of appropriate additives and dopants to prepare mesoporous alumina in a particular phase required. In this research, we have made mesoporous aluminas with suitable surface area and pore volume distribution without adding any surfactant and studied the effect of adding alcohol and metal salts, as well as changing the primary aluminum source on the desired alumina. It is emphasized that synthesized porous γ-alumina catalyst was prepared through surfactant-free sol-gel process using inexpensive raw materials and better structural properties were shown in the presence of this catalyst compared to previously reported aluminas. To best of our knowledge there is no report to synthesize γ-alumina with pore volume larger than 0.8 (cm3/g) in the absence of organic template reagents. High pore volume and surface area usually obtained by aluminum alkoxide starting material in the presence OTR reagents. Also, the catalytic performance of the synthesized γ-alumina sample in methanol dehydration reaction was evaluated at different temperatures and compared with the Merck γ-alumina. Different solid acid catalysts including zeolites, composite oxides and γ-Al2O3 can catalyze methanol dehydration to dimethyl ether according to the literature [22–24]. It should be pointed out that methanol dehydration is an indirect, potential and desirable process for dimethyl ether production in views of thermodynamics and economy [25–27]. Recent studies have shown that catalysts including medium to weak acid sites are more favorable for this reaction [28]. Therefore, γ-aluminas with lower acid strength than zeolites are more appropriate for catalytic dehydration of methanol. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and characterization techniques Aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), Aluminum sulfate (Al2(SO4)3·18H2O), Aluminum chloride (Al(Cl)3·6H2O), d-glucose, Cerium(III) nitrate (Ce(NO₃)₃.6H₂O), Magnesium nitrate (Mg(NO₃)₂.6H₂O), Gadolinium(III) nitrate (Gd(NO₃)3.6H₂O) and Lanthanum(III) nitrate (La(NO₃)₃.6H₂O) were purchased from Merck company. All commercially available solvents such as ammonia (25%) and Isopropyl alcohol and other compounds were used without further purification. X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was acquired by STOE X-Ray Diffractometer Tube Anode: Cu Wavelenghth 1.5406 A° (Cu Kα, Filter Ni). FT-IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets using Thermo Nicolet iS5 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was obtained with a TEM Philips EM 208S microscope. The specific surface area was determined by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method (BET) using Micromeritics Instrument Corporation TriStar II 3020 V1.03 (V1.03), and the pore volume and pore size distribution were calculated from the desorption branch of the isotherm as measured by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda method (BJH). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a SDTA-851e instrument at the heating rate of 10 °C/min. 2.2 Synthesis procedure First, aluminum nitrate solution with molar ratio of 0.5 mol/L was prepared. This solution was then slowly added to the reaction vessel containing 50 cc of deionized water together with the ammonia solution (4%). The temperature was maintained during the reaction in the range of 80–90 °C and the pH of 8–9. After 2 h, the prepared gel was aging for 20 h at room temperature. In the following step, the obtained gel was filtered and washed severally with distilled water, dispersed in ethanol for 30 min and finally dried at 80 °C for 16 h. The synthesized pseudo-boehmite product was labeled as BN3. XRD and BET analyzes were performed to identify the sample. 2.2.1 Effect of alcohol The previous step was repeated with the difference that isopropanol was added to the reaction mixture in the amount of 10% by weight of the starting material. The obtained gel was washed, dried and then calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to produce γ-alumina. This product was labeled as BN8-C. 2.2.2 Effect of changing the aluminum source Aluminum salts were mixed in a molar ratio of nitrate: sulfate of 8:2. Other reaction conditions were repeated as in Section 2.2. The sample synthesized in this step was named BN11. In another experiment, the synthesis reaction was performed in reaction mixture; aluminum nitrate: aluminum sulfate: aluminum chloride with molar ratio of 8:2:2. This sample was labeled as BNS-Cl. 2.2.3 Effect of glucose as an additive To investigate the effect of addition of glucose, d-glucose was added to the reaction mixture in the amount of 3% by weight of the starting material in order to synthesize BN8 and BN11 samples. The prepared products in this step were labeled as BN8G and BN11G respectively. Finally, the XRD and BET analyzes were repeated before and after calcination step. 2.2.4 Effect of dopants Each of the following salts such as cerium nitrate, magnesium nitrate, lanthanum nitrate and gadolinium nitrate were added as dopants to the synthesized BN8 sample in separate experiments and in the amount of 1% by weight of the final produced material. The reaction products were named as BN8-Ce, BN8-Mg, BN8-La and BN8-Gd respectively. To study the effect of metal salts on thermal stability of γ-alumina, BN8 sample and all the products which obtained in this section were calcinated at 800 °C for 12 h. Then, BET analyzes of the samples were recorded and compared. 2.3 Reactor test The reactor test was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor at different temperatures; with a feed flow rate of weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) 2.3 h − 1 at atmospheric pressure in the presence of nitrogen as a carrier gas. Also, the amount of catalyst loading was 3 g in all cases. The performance system is composed of reactor set, feed stream mass flow control and gas analysis parts. Brooks 5850 E series flow controllers (MFC) have been used in this system. Additionally, the outlet current from the reactor is sent to a condenser in which the temperature is reduced to 0 °C to separate the steam and unreacted methanol from the product. Finally, the methanol conversion and product selectivity were monitored by gas chromatography (Varian 3800 RGA equipped with TCD and FID) by the following equations [29]: (1) Conversion ( CH 3 OH ) % = n CH 3 OH , in − n CH 3 OH , Out n CH 3 OH , in × 100 (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( DME ) % = 2 × n DME , Out n CH 3 OH , in − n CH 3 OH , Out 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of mesoporous γ-alumina samples Various mesoporous γ-alumina samples were synthesized via a multistep procedure as displayed in Scheme 1. In the first step, aluminum salt and ammonia solution were mixed and stirred in the reaction vessel containing deionized water within 80–90 °C temperature. The pH adjustment of the precursor solution was kept between 8 and 9 using ammonia solutions. Afterwards, aging, washing and drying step were carried out respectively. Finally, the obtained gel was calcinated in furnace to produce γ-alumina. It should be mentioned that during the synthesis of γ-alumina from the pseudo-boehmite precursor, the parameters such as synthesis method, raw materials, washing, drying and aging step for the final powder can affect the surface area, pore volume and pore size of the produced alumina [30–33]. Also, use of additives and dopants such as metal ions could improve textural properties and mesoporosities, enhance catalytic performance and thermal stability [34–37]. In this regard, effect of addition of metal salts, alcohol, glucose and change of Al-source were studied separately. The name of prepared aluminas and materials used for synthesis were listed in Table 1 . The XRD patterns of all prepared samples were obtained with X-ray diffraction analysis (Fig. 1 and Fig. 2 ). The diffraction peaks of the pseudo-boehmite samples at 2θ = 14, 28, 38, 48, 64, 71 are in agreement with the database in JCPDS file No. 21–1307 [38]. It should be noted that the factors such as addition of alcohol, addition of d-glucose and changing the aluminum source do not affect the XRD patterns. In the XRD pattern of the calcined samples (Fig. 2), three characteristic peaks (2θ = 36, 46, and 66), corresponding to (311), (400), and (440) Bragg reflections, respectively, were observed. These peaks are consistent with the pattern previously reported for γ-alumina sample (JCPDS file No.10–0425) [38]. Comparison of Figs. 1 and 2 shows that the synthesis of alumina in the presence of metal salts does not cause a noticeable change in the XRD spectral pattern. The structural properties of pseudo-boehmite and γ-Al2O3 samples prepared by means of nitrogen adsorption-desorption study were summarized in Table 2 . It has been observed that the use of isopropanol in the reaction mixture, helped significantly in improvement of textural properties of alumina support. On the other hand, addition of d-glucose in the way of synthesis procedure of BN8 and BN11 samples tends to decreasing surface area, pore size and pore volume. The results show that the mentioned parameters are not affected by changing the aluminum source. Therefore, BN8 was found to be the best sample in terms of reported structural properties. All sample prepared, in the absence of organic reagent template, have significant pore volume of 0.6 to 0.94 (cm3/g) and pore size of 12 to 14 nm accompanied with high surface area. Accordingly, effect of addition of metal salts was studied in BN8 synthesis. As depicted in Table 3 , calcination of BN8 sample at 800 °C tends to decreasing surface area and pore volume but increasing pore size of particles. Also, the addition of metal salts in all cases increased the surface area compared to the sample without metal salt except in the presence of magnesium salt, which caused a slight reduction in surface area. Pore volume and pore size have also increased in the presence of all metal salts except for the particle size parameter for lanthanum salt, which had a very small decrease. Generally, it can be concluded that gadolinium salt, among other metal salts, has improved all three parameters of surface area, pore volume and pore size. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis of the synthesized aluminas was performed for determining surface areas from nitrogen adsorption isotherms. Fig. 3 illustrated the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore-size distribution curves for γ-Al2O3 samples. The pore size distribution of all products is in the range of 2–50 nm, which indicates that the resultant samples are mesoporous. Based on IUPAC classification, all the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the samples represented a type IV adsorption branch with H3-type hysteresis loop, characteristic of slit-shaped pores [39]. According to the BJH curves, the pore-size distributions of BN8-C, BN8-G-C, BN11-C, BN11-G-Cand BNS-Cl samples have presented 11, 10, 9.90, 7.70 and 9 nm respectively. Moreover, the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were reported for the synthesized γ-aluminas in the presence of different kinds of metal salts (Fig. 4 ). All these isotherms also exhibited a type IV adsorption branch with H3-type hysteresis loop. The observed pore-size distributions for BN8-C, BN8-C-Ce, BN8-C-Mg, BN8-C-Gd and BN8-C-La samples, which calcinated at 800 °C for 12 h; are 15, 16.30, 15.90, 16.80 and 14.90 nm respectively. The FT-IR spectroscopy was applied for the characterization of synthesized samples before and after being calcinated (Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 ). The bands above 3000 cm−1 can be ascribed to the stretching vibration of the OH groups of pseudo-boehmite, alcohol and adsorbed water. The absorption bands in the lower frequency range at 483, 500, 742, and 750 cm−1 are attributed to the Al-O stretching and bending vibrations (Fig. 5a and Fig. 5b). The FT-IR spectra represents intensive bands at about 1376, 1384, 1629 and 1633 cm−1 which corresponds to the stretching and bending vibration modes of OH groups in the hydroxide structure and water molecules. The bands observed at 900, 1079 cm−1 are associated to the symmetrical and asymmetrical Al-O-H deformation vibration modes [40]. Additionally, the characteristic peaks at 548 and 815 cm−1 ascribed to the stretching and bending Al-O vibrations [38,41] can be clearly observed in Fig 0.6. To note, BN8 has shown a strong broad band centered at 3595 cm−1 which shows presence of isopropyl alcohol in the structure possibly due to hydrogen bonds. Therefore larger pore volume and pore sizes in the presence of alcohol have been resulted. The morphology and textural properties of the synthesized γ-Al2O3 were also studied by scanning and transmission electron microscopy (Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 ). The SEM images of the used BN8-C and Merck γ-alumina catalysts were obtained at the end of the reactor test process (after 48 h). Comparing SEM images revealed a uniform morphology for the synthesized BN8-C Catalyst unlike Merck γ-alumina. It also shows nanostructure of BN8 and aggregated micro-scale particles for commercial alumina. The TEM images of BN8 sample clearly represent a nano-sized Rod-shaped morphology, which is consistent with the pore-size distribution results reported from BJH curves. As shown in Fig. 8, the presence of hollow cavities refers to the mesoporosity structure of synthesized BN8 sample. As shown in Fig. 9 , NH3-TPD analysis was performed to study the type, density and distribution of acidic sites for the prepared γ-alumina (BN8-C sample) and Merck γ-alumina catalyst. The acidic sites on the surface of synthesized alumina sample mainly consist of three types: weak (60–280 °C), medium (280–450 °C), and strong (450–700 °C). This is while the second peak is not observed for commercial alumina. Total acidic sites are clearly much higher on the prepared mesoporous alumina to that of commercial one. More acidic sites on the synthesized alumina is expected to result in more reactivity in catalytic tests. Additionally, the amount of total acidic sites of BN8-C and Merck γ-alumina catalysts are reported 1.43 and 0.79 (mmol NH3 /g Catalyst) respectively, according to the NH3-TPD profiles. 3.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic performance of the prepared γ-alumina (BN8-C sample) and Merck γ-alumina (as a reference) in methanol to DME reaction has been illustrated Fig. 10 , presenting the effects of reaction temperature. The methanol conversion was commonly raised in both samples by temperature showing a strong influence of this factor on the reaction. For instance, in the case of the BN8-C sample, the conversion was improved by increasing the temperature. The obtained results indicate that the synthesized γ-alumina displayed higher conversion compared to the Merck γ-alumina especially at lower temperatures. This observation can be attributed to the structural properties of the prepared BN8-C alumina (see Table 2). It must be noted that the reason for examining the catalytic activity of BN8-C sample was that this sample had desired structural properties among other synthesized γ-aluminas. To gain further insight on the performance of alumina catalysts, their selectivity in methanol dehydration reaction were investigated and compared with each other. The dimethyl ether and methane selectivities at different temperatures are displayed in Fig. 10. The best selectivity towards dimethyl ether for the synthesized BN8 catalyst is obtained at 300 °C, 350 °C, 200 °C and 400 °C respectively. Therefore, the optimum temperature in the presence of synthesized alumina is 300 °C due to 98% DME selectivity and 99% methanol conversion. The selectivity of the BN8 for DME reduces at 400 °C and considerable amount of methane is formed at this temperature. On the other hand, commercial alumina shows good selectivity similar to BN8 at 400 °C. Therefore it seems that synthesized mesostructured alumina can reduce the operational temperature of the process at least by 100 °C. Furthermore, the results revealed significant catalytic activity of BN8-C alumina sample in terms of dimethyl ether selectivity at low temperature of 200 °C compared with the Merck γ-alumina sample. As illustrated in Fig. 10, the best selectivity for conversion to methane is related to 400 °C for the synthesized BN8 alumina catalyst. Accordingly in this case, it can be concluded that the reaction continues to produce methane through further side reaction. This observation demonstrated the effects of reaction temperature on the selectivity towards dimethyl ether and methane. In addition, the influence of water was investigated in methanol dehydration reaction over prepared BN8-C catalyst in this research. Methanol conversion was obtained 80% and 76.8% at 300 °C in the presence of CH3OH/H2O with volume ratio of 75:25 and 50:50 respectively. Therefore, the results show that addition of water in the feed results in a substantial decrease of methanol conversion. It is concluded that water is acting as an inhibitor due to the competitive adsorption with methanol on catalytic active sites [42,43]. The time-on-stream (TOS) behavior of the synthesized alumina catalyst (BN8-C) was investigated to evaluate the catalyst stability over time at 300 °C (Fig. 11 ). This figure demonstrates that conversion efficiency of methanol increases with time gradually to about 99% and remains constant after the 60 h of experiment. The obtained results indicate a very good stability of the synthesized catalyst over 66 h. The TGA analysis was carried out on the used BN8-C catalyst at the end of the reactor test process (after 48 h). TGA diagram represents weight loss in three temperature ranges (Fig. 12 ). The first part is attributed to the loss of physically adsorbed water. The second and third parts are belong to the coke combustion or combustion of heavy hydrocarbons formed on the catalyst. The TGA proves that only 1% coke was formed on the prepared catalyst after 48 h which is very fascinating. Table 4 shows structural features and catalytic performance in methanol dehydration over prepared catalyst in this paper compared to the some reported data for synthesized aluminas in literatures. It is clear that the catalyst in the present investigation has better structural properties than most of aluminas reported, especially in terms of pore size and pore volume. Of course, it is emphasized that this nano-sized porous γ-alumina catalyst was prepared through surfactant-free sol-gel process using inexpensive raw materials in the presence of atmospheric pressure unlike other synthesized aluminas which reported in the scientific literature. In addition, catalytic reactor test was allowed to proceed for 66 h in 300 °C and methanol conversion was remained constant after the 60 h of experiment. 4 Conclusion In this work, nano-sized porous γ-alumina samples have been synthesized via surfactant-free sol-gel method and calcination procedure using inexpensive starting materials including aluminum nitrate, ammonia and deionized water. Afterwards, the influence of some parameters such as addition of alcohol, metal salts and also effect of changing the aluminum source were examined. Furthermore, surface area and pore characteristics of obtained products were determined by N2 adsorption. It has been observed that the use of 10% isopropanol in water could improve pore volume and pore size of prepared γ-alumina. Metal salt in particular addition of gadolinium salt, could significantly improve the thermal stability of alumina. In order to investigate the comparative performance of synthesized and Merck γ-alumina samples, the methanol conversion and dimethyl ether selectivity of these catalysts were studied. The results showed that the catalyst activity was improved by raising the temperature. An obvious outcome of this study is the remarkable activity of prepared alumina catalyst in methanol dehydration reaction from 200 to 300 °C in terms of methanol conversion and selectivity compared with the Merck γ-alumina sample. It can be explained by the appropriate structural features of synthesized alumina catalyst. As a result, considering the importance of the surface area, pore volume and pore size in γ-alumina, improving these factors could enhance the catalytic activity and reduce temperature of the process. In general, based on the results of reactor tests, 300 °C which caused the highest DME selectivity and also methanol conversion, was determined to be the optimum reaction temperature. This catalyst is very stable and resistant to coke and its activity is resumed after 60 h run. Declaration of Competing Interest No potential conflict of interest was reported by the authors. coredata.dc:description: Different samples of mesoporous nano-sized γ-alumina were prepared through surfactant-free sol-gel process, using aluminum nitrate as precursor. The influence of variables such as addition of alcohol, metal salts and also effect of changing the aluminum source were investigated on the synthesis method. The products, which were obtained on different conditions, were then characterized by XRD, FT-IR, SEM, TEM. Moreover, textural properties were also measured by BET. To study thermal stability of prepared alumina; Cerium nitrate, magnesium nitrate, lanthanum nitrate and gadolinium nitrate were added as dopants. The catalytic performance of the synthesized mesoporous alumina (with a surface area of ​​272 m2/g, pore volume of 0.94 cm3/g and pore size of 13.8 nm) was studied for the methanol conversion to dimethyl ether, and the result was compared by commercial γ-alumina. Synthesized mesostructured catalyst has comparable activity and DME selectivity at 300°C to that of commercial alumina at 400 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Dimethyl ether from methanol on mesoporous γ-alumina catalyst prepared from surfactant free highly porous pseudo-boehmite
